doc.title: Global Economics Wrap-Up: August 29, 2025
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/Global Economics Wrap-Up August 29 2025Global Economics Wrap-Up August 29 2025_2025-08-29

passages.text: Monthly inflation roundup:
In July, you core inflation surprised to the upside again in the UK (largely driven by airfares) but was in line with consensus expectations elsewhere.

July core inflation ticked down in Canada \((+2.5\%)\) yoy, prior \(+2.6\%\) was sideways in Japan (new core \(+3.4\%\) yoy), and increased in the UK \((+3.76\%)\) , prior \(+3.66\%\) ) and the US (PCE \(+2.88\%\) , prior \(+2.77\%\) ). Our July sequential trimmed core inflation measures increased in Japan \((2.1\%\) month- over- month annualized vs. \(1.7\%\) ) but ticked down in Canada \((1.6\%\) vs. \(2.9\%\) ), the UK \((2.4\%\) vs. \(3.6\%\) ), the US \((2.1\%\) vs. \(2.8\%\) ), and the Euro area \((2.5\%\) vs. \(2.6\%\) ).

At yearend, we forecast you core inflation to climb to \(+3.2\%\) in the US (reflecting tariff pressures) but decline to \(+3.7\%\) in the UK, \(+3.0\%\) in Canada, \(+2.2\%\) in Japan, and \(+2.0\%\) in the Euro Area.
We revised up our core and headline forecasts in the UK by 0.2pp and revised down our headline forecast in Canada by 0.2pp.
Q2 earnings season commentary shows that companies are using a range of strategies to adapt to the changing environment:
Company sentiment about the consumer outlook rebounded in Q2 after falling sharply in Q1, but the H2 outlook remains challenging because real income growth is likely to slow.

Among companies that discussed how they are handling tariff costs, three- fourths said they were negotiating with suppliers or adjusting their supply chain and half said they were passing costs through to customers.
Our company price announcement tracker has only increased modestly this year, but it has risen more meaningfully for companies with higher tariff exposure.

- The business investment tax incentives in the recent fiscal bill appear to have been widely anticipated, and likely as a result, companies did not meaningfully revise their capex guidance after its passage.
Our Q3 GDP tracking estimate stands at \(1.6\%\) (qoq annualized):

- Sales of new single-family homes declined by \(0.6\%\) , while the June growth rate was revised up by \(3.5\mathrm{pp}\) to \(+4.1\%\) .- Core capital goods shipments increased by \(0.7\%\) in July and the June growth rate was revised up by \(0.1\mathrm{pp}\) to \(+0.4\%\) .- The goods trade deficit widened by \(\) 18.7\mathrm{bn}\(to\) \ \(103.6\mathrm{bn}\) .- Goods imports rose by \(\) 18.6\mathrm{bn}\(, likely reflecting frontloading ahead of tariffs that were set to go into effect in August.- Personal income increased by \(0.4\%\) and consumer spending increased by \(0.5\%\) in July.
We answer main questions on the French confidence vote:

- French PM Bayrou has called a confidence vote on September 8.  
- Opposition stance suggests the government will likely lose and resign, with markets pricing over \(80\%\) odds he leaves by end-September.  
- Post-collapse, Macron can either appoint a new government under the current Parliament or call snap parliamentary elections.  
- Under a new government, a less ambitious budget could still pass by year-end with a baseline deficit of \(5.2\%\) of GDP in 2026.  
- If snap elections occur, policy uncertainty widens the budget outcome range.  
- Higher deficits would lift debt-to-GDP and revive rating risks.
We expect Euro area August core inflation of \(2.21\%\) yoy:

- The flash estimate of French headline HICP inflation in August was \(0.8\%\) yoy, weaker than consensus but close to our expectations.  
- Spanish flash HICP inflation was slightly above our expectations of \(2.6\%\) yoy but below consensus at \(2.7\%\) yoy in August.  
- Italian flash HICP inflation came in at \(1.7\%\) yoy in August, slightly below our expectations and consensus.  
- German headline HICP inflation was \(2.1\%\) yoy in August, slightly above \(2.0\%\) yoy regional CPI data suggested and consensus.  
- Folding in the country releases, we now expect Euro area headline inflation of \(2.02\%\) yoy and core inflation of \(2.21\%\) yoy.
Asia/EM Economics 8/28/25 9:15PM ET
China's equity prices and government bond yields increased despite mixed
Our latest high- frequency data tracker showed that on- the- ground activity was mostly stable from July to August, but the latest property and labor market data remained weak.
- youth unemployment rate increased to \(17.8\%\) (vs. \(17.1\%\) last July).

- QSES requires rose and government bond yields increased in July and August on the back of better news on US-China tariffs and increased focus on "anti-involution" efforts by policymakers to reduce excessive price-cutting.

- Our conversations with onshore investors suggest that local investors are less concerned about China's export outlook compared with late June and largely expect authorities to deliver the \(5\%\) GDP growth target.
- Reinforcing our view that policy easing in 2025 will remain reactive and conservative.
US tariffs on India rise to \(50\%\) :

- An additional 25pp of US tariffs on imports from India "due to India's direct or indirect importation of Russian Federation oil" are now in effect.  
- India, along with Brazil, has the highest headline tariff rate among US trading partners.  
- We estimated a drag of at least 0.3pp on Indian GDP growth from each of the two 25pp tariff increases.
Most EM central banks still biased to ease:

- The Bank of Korea kept its policy rate on hold at \(2.5\%\) ; we continue to expect one more 25bp cut in October to \(2.25\%\) .  
- The central bank of Philippines cut its policy rate by 25bp; we continue to expect 25bp cuts in Q4 and Q1 2026, to \(4.5\%\) .  
- The central bank of Hungary kept its policy rate unchanged at \(6.5\%\) .  
- Egypt's central bank cut the policy rate by 200bp to \(22\%\) ; we forecast an additional 300bp of cuts in Q4.
GDP Forecast Tracker: GS vs. Consensus

Note: All forecasts calculated on calendar year basis except when otherwise stated. IMF forecasts used for India 2026 consensus when quarters not available in Bloomberg. Global growth aggregates use market FX country weights.
Source: Bloomberg, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
